results.title: Sea in the blood
results.creator_credit: Robert Reid and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: In Cyprus, folk history tales tell of children dying from anaemia. Village elders know that significant numbers of children have died and continue to die of a disease of the blood, called thalassemia. The video explains the incidence and treatment of thalassemia in villages of the Mediterranean. A doctor in the British Army, Colin Bate, gives accounts of the disease in Cyprus villages and specific cases are discussed. Techniques for the antenatal diagnosis of thalassemia are explained and the idea of genetic engineering is explored.

results.title: Sea Festivals of Hong Kong
results.creator_credit: Ben R. Hart, J Murray and Hong Kong Film Unit
results.brief_description: The sea between Hong Kong and neighbouring islands is the setting for many festivals and ceremonies in Southeast Asia. A beautifully photographed film on the junk and sampan dwellers, their life, fishing and in particular their colorful religious festivals.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ben R. Hart, J Murray and Hong Kong Film Unit

results.title: Sea eagles
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A recruiting film for the Royal Australian Navy, showing life in Australia’s Fleet Air Arm. We see how living on an aircraft carrier is exciting and full of non-stop action. We also see how Australia’s Navy aviators fly helicopters for rescue and recovery, as well as attack, and the striking force of the fixed wing Skyhawk jets and the two-engined Tracker aircraft as they come and go from the deck of their seabound base.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David E. Barrow, Peter Johnson and Film Australia

results.title: Sea dream
results.creator_credit: Ellen Besen, Margaret Pettigrew and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Children, like adults, have days that go wrong. This film shows how one little girl overcomes the day’s frustrations by diving into an underwater fantasy where she spends time with her friend, the lady octopus. After playing many wonderful games together, the little girl re-enters the world of reality, feeling fine and refreshed. Animation by Bill Speers. (Awards: New York, Ottawa)

results.title: Sea creatures
results.brief_description: An underwater look at the inhabitants of the Red Sea. These creatures appear to be from another world yet they are a very real part of the Sea’s ecosystem. Imaginative music and sound effects heighten the beautiful underwater photography. This film is a comment upon the fragile web of life. Film without narration.

results.title: Sea Changers
results.brief_description: More and more people are moving to Port Fairy to be part of a strong, creative and social community. We meet Katie Wise who came to Port Fairy for a visit, and has been there for 10 years now, managing the school canteen and teaching the kids the benefit of healthy food. For Helen and Ben Fennessy, Port Fairy is a place that gives them great solitude to be able to do what they like creatively. Judy and Victor Gillatt explored the town while on holiday in 1973, and the more they explored, the more they liked.

results.title: Sea area: Forties
results.creator_credit: John Armstrong, British Petroleum and Pelican Films
results.brief_description: The exciting story of how the sponsors developed their Forties Field in the North Sea and were the first to bring oil ashore in quantity. The film also shows how BP have endeavoured to respect the surrounding countryside and the wishes and well-being of local people.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Armstrong, British Petroleum and Pelican Films

results.title: Sea animals
results.creator_credit: Tom Gordon, Video School and Dorling Kindersley Vision
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “See how they grow”.
Another interesting episode in this instructional series on animals designed for young children. This program focuses on four sea creatures from infancy to adulthood. The animals featured are the Ray, a cousin of the shark; the Pipe-Fish, a fascinating eel-like fish; the Cuttlefish whose skeleton is a familiar sight on the beach and the Hermit Crab which hides in a shell to preserve its privacy.
